words.Etymology_Snippet: From Ancient Greek ἀγών (agṓn, “assembly, contest”). Doublet of αγών (agón), a borrowing.
words.Ancient_Context: πολλοὺσ ἀ. ἐξιών 'of Hercules' (Sophocles Tragicus Tr. 159) | ψυχῆσ ἀ. τὸν προκείμενον πέρι 'struggle for life and death' (Euripides Tragicus Or. 847) | οὐ λόγων ἔθ' ἁγών 'now is not the time for words' (Euripides Tragicus Philo Judaeus 588)

words.Etymology_Snippet: From Ancient Greek τᾰλαιπωρῐ́ᾱ (tălaipōrĭ́ā), from Ancient Greek ταλαίπωρος (talaípōros, “suffering,
words.Ancient_Context: τ. βίοσ (Sophocles Tragicus OC 91) | τὸ τ 'hardihood' (Aristophanes Comicus Nu. 414) | ταλαίπωροσ 'suffering, distressed, miserable' (Sophocles Tragicus OC 14)

words.Etymology_Snippet: Learned borrowing from Koine Greek πολιτισμός (politismós), from Ancient Greek πολίτης (polítēs) + -
From Ancient Greek δυσκολία (duskolía), equivalent to δύσκολος (dýskolos, “difficult, hard”) + -ία (
words.Ancient_Context: δυσκολία 'discontent, peevishness' (Aristophanes Comicus V. 106) | δυσκολία 'discontent, peevishness' (Plato Philosophus R. 411c)
πρὸσ φόβουσ καὶ λύπασ (Plato Philosophus Lg. 633d)

words.Etymology_Snippet: From Ancient Greek πόλεμος (pólemos).
words.Ancient_Context: πόλεμον ἄρασθαι 'levy war' (Aeschylus Tragicus Supp. 342) | οὐ πόλεμον ἐπαγγέλλεισ, 'i.e. that is good news' (Plato Philosophus Lg. 702d) | ἢ τοῖσιν ἢ τοῖσ π. αἴρεσθαι μέγαν (Aeschylus Tragicus Supp. 439)

words.Etymology_Snippet: Inherited from Ancient Greek καταστροφή (katastrophḗ).
words.Ancient_Context: κ. βίου 'i.e. death' (Sophocles Tragicus OC 103) | ἄνευ δὲ λύπησ οὐδαμοῦ καταστροφή (Aeschylus Tragicus Supp. 442) | τὸ τέλοσ αὐτῶν τῆσ κ. 'the event of their life's end' (Polybius Historicus 6.8.6)

ἀ. τοῦ ἀδικεῖν 'for wrongdoing' (Plato Philosophus R. 359b) | τῶν πραγμάτων 'for political action' (Aristoteles Philosophus Pol. 1314a23) | ἀδυναμία 'inability, incapacity' (Herodotus Historicus 8.111)

words.Etymology_Snippet: From Ancient Greek δικαίωμα (dikaíōma), by surface analysis, δίκαιος (díkaios, “just”) + -ωμα (-oma)
words.Ancient_Context: δικαιώματα Ἑλληνίδων πόλεων, 'compiled by' (Aristoteles Philosophus) | δικαίωμα 'judgement, penalty,' (Plato Philosophus Lg. 864e) | δικαίωμα 'justification, plea of right,' (Thucydides Historicus 1.41)

words.Etymology_Snippet: Inherited from Byzantine Greek δουλειά (douleiá), from Hellenistic Koine Greek δουλεία (douleía) wit
words.Ancient_Context: ἢν . . ἡ δ. ἐπανιστῆται 'if the slave-class rise in rebellion' (Thucydides Historicus 5.23) | δουλεύοντα δουλείαισ ἐμαῖσ (Euripides Tragicus Ba. 803) | ἡ τῶν κρεισσόνων δ. 'imposed by them' (Thucydides Historicus 1.8)

words.LSJ_Definition: one who has left his home, wanderer, migrant
words.Ancient_Context: μοῦνοι οὐ μετανάσται Ἑλλήνων 'of the Athenians' (Herodotus Historicus 7.161) | μ. γενόμενοι ὑπὸ ἐθνῶν 'Prisc' (p.341) | ψυχὴ σώματοσ μ. 'a fugitive from' (Philo Judaeus 2.462)

words.Etymology_Snippet: From Ancient Greek κόπος (“striking; fatigue”). See κόπτω (kóptō, “cut”).
words.LSJ_Definition: striking, beating; ὀξύχειρι σὺν κόπῳ; κτύπῳ
words.Ancient_Context: κόπου ὕπο 'from very weariness' (Euripides Tragicus Ba. 634) | κόπουσ παρέχειν τινί 'to give trouble' (Ev.Matt. 26.10) | κόπῳ κόπον λύειν 'prov. in' (Oribasius Medicus Eupolis Comicus 1.2.8)

words.Etymology_Snippet: Learned borrowing from Ancient Greek δουλεία (douleía).
words.Ancient_Context: ἢν . . ἡ δ. ἐπανιστῆται 'if the slave-class rise in rebellion' (Thucydides Historicus 5.23) | δουλεύοντα δουλείαισ ἐμαῖσ (Euripides Tragicus Ba. 803) | ἡ τῶν κρεισσόνων δ. 'imposed by them' (Thucydides Historicus 1.8)

words.Etymology_Snippet: Learned borrowing from Ancient Greek χάος (kháos). For sense disorder, mess, semantic loan from Fren
words.Ancient_Context: τὸ χ. τοῦ ἐφ' ἑκάτερα ἀπείρου αἰῶνοσ, 'of infinite time' (Marcus Antoninus Imperator 4.3) | χάουσ κύνα, 'of Cerberus' (APl. 4.91) | χάοσ 'chaos,' (Aristophanes Comicus Av. 693)

words.Etymology_Snippet: Inherited from Ancient Greek ἀνάγκη (anánkē, “necessity”).
words.Ancient_Context: ἀνάγκη δαιμόνων, αἱ ἐκ θεῶν ἀνάγκαι, 'fate, destiny' (Euripides Tragicus Philo Judaeus 1000) | πολλή μ' ἀνάγκη, 'with which an inf. may always be supplied' (Euripides Tragicus Med. 1013) | ἀνάγκη ἐστί, 'c. inf., it must be that.., is necessary that.., cf' (Ilias)

words.Etymology_Snippet: From Ancient Greek βία (bía).
words.Ancient_Context: βίᾳ τινόσ 'against one's will, in spite of him' (Aeschylus Tragicus Thucydides Historicus 746) | Κράτοσ Βία τε (Aeschylus Tragicus Pr. 12) | οὐκ ἔστι βίη φρεσίν (Ilias 3.45)

words.Etymology_Snippet: From the Ancient Greek κάτοικος (kátoikos).
words.Ancient_Context: κ. 'is in' (Aeschylus Tragicus Ag. 1286) | κάτοικοσ 'military colonists' (Aeschylus Tragicus Ag. 1286)

words.Etymology_Snippet: From Ancient Greek ἄνεργος (ánergos).
words.LSJ_Definition: not done; ἔργα ἄ.,; facta infecta
words.Ancient_Context: ἔργα ἄ., 'Lat. facta infecta' (Euripides Tragicus Hel. 363) | ἄνεργοσ 'facta infecta,' (Euripides Tragicus Hel. 363) | ἐνεργόσ, 'v.l. in' (Josephus Historicus AJ 16.2.4)

words.Etymology_Snippet: From Koine Greek παθαίνω (pathaínō), from Ancient Greek ἔπαθον (épathon) the aorist of πάσχω (páskhō
words.Modern_Def: to happen to (something negative), be wrong with, suffer, undergo
words.Ancient_Context: παθαίνω 'fill with emotion' (Thucydides Historicus 23)

words.Etymology_Snippet: Learned borrowing from Ancient Greek καταβάλλω (katabállō), semantic loan from French accabler. By s
words.Ancient_Context: κρεῖον μέγα κάββαλεν ἐν πυρὸσ αὐγῇ (Ilias 9.206) | ὅταν δὲ κρηπὶσ μὴ καταβληθῇ . . ὀρθῶσ (Euripides Tragicus HF 1261) | κ. εἴσ τι 'throw away upon a thing' (Plato Philosophus Lg. 960e)

words.Etymology_Snippet: From Ancient Greek ὑφίσταμαι (huphístamai), middle/passive form of ὑφίστημι (huphístēmi).
words.Ancient_Context: ἦ ῥ' ἅλιον τὸν μῦθον ὑπέστημεν . . , ἀπονέεσθαι 'vain was the promise we made.., that he would return' (Ilias 5.715) | γνώμασ ὑποστήσασ σοφάσ 'having laid them as a foundation, having begun with them' (Sophocles Tragicus Aj. 1091) | ὤσ οἱ ὑπέστην 'as I promised him' (Ilias 15.75)

words.Etymology_Snippet: Inherited from Ancient Greek στηρίζω (stērízō). See also Proto-Slavic *starati (“to try, attempt”),
words.Ancient_Context: ἴριδασ ἐν νέφεϊ στήριξε 'sets rainbows in the cloud' (Ilias 11.28) | οὐδὲ πόδεσσιν εἶχε στηρίξασθαι 'he could not get a firm footing' (Ilias 21.242) | κακὸν κακῷ ἐστήρικτο 'evil was set upon evil' (Ilias 16.111)

words.Etymology_Snippet: Inherited from Koine Greek δουλεύω (douleúō), from Ancient Greek δουλόω (doulóō, “to enslave”), from
words.Ancient_Context: τό τ' ἄρχειν καὶ τὸ δ. δίχα (Aeschylus Tragicus Pr. 927) | τῇ γῇ δ. 'make oneself a slave to one's land, i. e. give up rights that one may keep it' (Thucydides Historicus 1.81) | δ. τῷ καιρῷ 'accommodate oneself to the occasion' (AP 9.441)

words.Etymology_Snippet: Inherited from Ancient Greek πιστεύω (pisteúō).
words.Ancient_Context: λόγοισ ἐμοῖσι πίστευσον τάδε 'believe my words herein' (Euripides Tragicus Hel. 710) | ὡσ οὐχ ὑπείξων οὐδὲ πιστεύσων λέγεισ (Sophocles Tragicus OT 625) | χαλεπὰ παντὶ ἑξῆσ τεκμηρίῳ πιστεῦσαι 'although it is hard to believe every single bit of evidence about them' (Thucydides Historicus 1.20)

words.Etymology_Snippet: Learned borrowing from Ancient Greek κινδυνεύω (kinduneúō).
words.Modern_Def: to be in danger, to be in peril, to be at risk
words.LSJ_Definition: make a venture, take a risk
words.Ancient_Context: κινδυνεύουσι οἱ ἄνθρωποι οὗτοι γόητεσ εἶναι 'they run a risk of being reputed conjurers' (Herodotus Historicus 4.105) | τοῦ χωρίου κινδυνεύοντοσ 'the post being in peril' (Thucydides Historicus 4.8) | κινδυνεύσομεν βοηθεῖν 'we shall probably have to assist' (Plato Philosophus Tht. 164e)

words.LSJ_Definition: mark by boundaries : set a limit
words.Ancient_Context: ἄνευ τοῦ περιορίζοντοσ 'without any boundary, ib' (719e)

words.Etymology_Snippet: Learnedly, from Ancient Greek προτείνω (proteínō, “put forward, propose”), from προ- (pro-) + τείνω
words.Ancient_Context: π. χεῖρα δεξιάν 'offer, tender it as a pledge' (Sophocles Tragicus Philo Judaeus 1292) | ψυχὴν . . προτείνων (Sophocles Tragicus Aj. 1270) | β ́; κέρδοσ (Aeschylus Tragicus Pr. 777)

words.Etymology_Snippet: Learned borrowing from Ancient Greek καταλαμβάνω (katalambánō); compare the inherited doublet καταλα
words.Ancient_Context: τῆσ νυκτὸσ -λαμβανούσησ 'as night was coming on' (Diodorus Siculus Historicus 20.86) | παρὰ τοῦ βασιλέωσ . . δωροδοκήματα 'dub. l. in' (Pl.Com. 119.1) | νόμοισ, ἔθεσι κατειλημμένα 'enforced' (Aristoteles Philosophus Pol. 1324b22)

words.Etymology_Snippet: From Ancient Greek φεύγω (pheúgō, “flee”) (the sense "leave" since mediaeval times. From Proto-Helle
words.Ancient_Context: βέλτερον, ὃσ φεύγων προφύγῃ κακὸν ἠὲ ἁλώῃ 'it is better that one should flee and escape than stay and be caught' (Ilias 14.81) | φύγε λαιψηρὸν δρόμον 'ran the course full swiftly' (Pindarus Lyricus P. 9.121) | ἔφευγε μὴ εἰδέναι 'pleaded ignorance' (Sophocles Tragicus Ant. 263)

words.Etymology_Snippet: From Modern Greek πάρα (pára, “very much”) + μένω (méno, “stay”).
words.Modern_Def: to stay, remain at a place for too long, more than expected
words.Ancient_Context: τὸ μόρσιμον γὰρ τόν τ' ἐλεύθερον μένει 'awaits him' (Aeschylus Tragicus Ch. 103) | μ. ἀπὸ ἧσ ἀλόχοιο 'stay away, be absent from' (Ilias 2.292) | ἦ μένετε Τρῶασ σχεδὸν ἐλθέμεν 'wait ye for the Trojans to come nigh?' (Ilias 4.247)

words.Etymology_Snippet: From Ancient Greek καταρρέω (“fall into ruins”). Morphologically, from κατα- (“fully”) + ρέω (“flow”
words.Ancient_Context: σιγᾷ κατερρύη μέλοσ 'dub. in' (Pindarus Lyricus Fr. 177) | αἷμα καταρρέον ἐξ ὠτειλῆσ (Ilias 4.149) | οἱ δὲ ἐμπαλασσόμενοι κατέρρεον 'i. e. into the river' (Thucydides Historicus 7.84)

words.Etymology_Snippet: From Ancient Greek πλούσιος (ploúsios, “rich, wealthy, noble”).
words.Ancient_Context: πλουσίῳ χαίρειν γένει 'in his rich and lordly race' (Sophocles Tragicus OT 1070) | ἐμοὶ πένησ . . πλουσίου μᾶλλον ξένοσ (Euripides Tragicus El. 395) | πτωχὸσ ἀντὶ πλουσίου (Sophocles Tragicus OT 455)

words.Etymology_Snippet: Inherited from Ancient Greek ᾰ̓δῠ́νᾰτος (ădŭ́nătos, “unable, inefficient, weak”). By surface analysi
words.Ancient_Context: ὅσονπερ δ. εἰμι 'with inf. omitted' (Euripides Tragicus Or. 523) | δ. λῦσαι 'mighty to loose' (Pindarus Lyricus O. 10(11).9) | ώτατοι καὶ τοῖσ σώμασιν καὶ τοῖσ χρήμασιν λῃτουργεῖν 'Decr. ap' (Aristoteles Philosophus Athenaeus Grammaticus 29.5)

words.Etymology_Snippet: Inherited from Ancient Greek ἄδικος (ádikos).
words.Ancient_Context: τὸ δίκαιον καὶ τὸ ἄ., τὰ δίκαια καὶ τὰ ἄ. 'right and wrong' (Plato Philosophus Grg. 460a) | ἡ ἄ. . . συναγωγὴ ἀνδρὸσ καὶ γυναικόσ 'the unrighteous union' (Plato Philosophus Tht. 150a) | ἄ. ἐν τῷ ἀστραγαλίζειν 'one who plays unfairly' (Plato Philosophus Alcaeus Lyricus 1.110b)

τῶν παρὰ τοῖσ ἄλλοισ εὑρημένων ἱ. 'well-informed respecting.. or able to recount' (Aristoteles Philosophus Rhetores Graeci 1359b32) | ἐξηγητικώτερον ἢ -ώτερον 'of Aristotle's method in HA' (Antigonus Carystius Paradoxographus Mir. 60) | -κῶσ 'scientifically, accurately' (Aristoteles Philosophus GA 757b35)

words.LSJ_Definition: front to front, face to face
relating to laws; αἴτια,; resting on law
words.Ancient_Context: ν. ὀνόματα 'law-terms' (Id. Meth. 2) | νομικόσ 'of law' (Sophocles Tragicus) | νομικόσ 'learned in the law,' (Plato Philosophus Min. 317e)

words.Etymology_Snippet:
Inherited from Ancient Greek μόνος (mónos).
Compare Mariupol Greek мо́нос (mónos), мо́ну (mónu).
words.Ancient_Context: ἀνδρῶν γε μοῦνοσ 'he and no other' (Sophocles Tragicus OC 1250) | σοῦ μόνοσ 'bereft of thee, without thee' (Sophocles Tragicus Aj. 511) | μόνα κατέχεσθαι ποιεῖ 'are unique for causing possession' (Plato Philosophus Smp. 215c)
ἀκραῖοσ 'dwelling on heights' (Euripides Tragicus Med. 1379) | ἀκραῖα,  'extremities' (Galenus Medicus 7.416)

words.Etymology_Snippet: From Ancient Greek κυρίως (kuríōs, “with full authority”), from Ancient Greek κύριος (kúrios, “lord,
words.LSJ_Definition: like a lord; master, with full authority
words.Ancient_Context: κ. αἰτεῖσθαι 'suo jure' (Sophocles Tragicus Philo Judaeus 63) | κ. ἔχειν 'to be fixed, hold good' (Id. Ag. 178) | κυρίωσ 'surely, by fixed decree' (Aeschylus Tragicus Ch. 785)

words.Etymology_Snippet: From Ancient Greek λόγῳ (lógōi), dative singular of λόγος (lógos, “reason, logic”), a calque of Fren
words.Modern_Def: because of, due to, owing to, on account of (as a consequence of)
words.Ancient_Context: μὴ φῦναι τὸν ἅπαντα νικᾷ λ. 'excels the whole account, i.e. is best of all' (Sophocles Tragicus OC 1225) | Τροίαν . . ἧσ ἁπανταχοῦ λ. 'whose fame, story fills the world' (Euripides Tragicus IT 517) | οὐκ ἔχει λόγον 'it is not arguable, i.e. reasonable' (Sophocles Tragicus El. 466)

words.Etymology_Snippet: From Ancient Greek χωρίς (khōrís).
words.Ancient_Context: περὶ τὸ ἓν καὶ χ. 'about the one and without [the one' (Aristoteles Philosophus Philo Judaeus 203a14) | χ. μὲν πρόγονοι, χ. δὲ μέτασσαι, χ. δ' αὖθ' ἕρσαι (Odyssea 9.221) | χ. τό τ' εἶναι καὶ τὸ μὴ νομίζεται (Euripides Tragicus Alcaeus Lyricus 528)

words.Etymology_Snippet:
From Ancient Greek κάτω (kátō).
Compare Mariupol Greek ка́ту (kátu).
words.Ancient_Context: ἄνω καὶ κάτω, ἄνω κάτω 'etc., (B' (Aeschylus Tragicus 11.2) | τὰ ἄνω 'the goal' (Plato Philosophus R. 613b) | ἐπισκύνιον κ. ἕλκεται (Ilias 17.136)

knots.Nuance: Plural gains one syllable (-δες/-δων). Stress moves forward one syllable in the plural to satisfy the antepenultimate rule.

Obligatory stress shift to the final syllable in Gen Pl (e.g., κορών), unless oxytone throughout. A few nouns derived from AG 3rd declension retain ancient/learned forms; some irregularly form Gen Pl in -άδων [17-19].
Singular forms follow other -η diagram but plurals tend to lean their Ancient forms (-εις; -εων)
Nouns ending in -η in the Nominative Singular are invariably Feminine.

knots.Description: Nouns in -ας (Parisyllabic, Gen. Pl. Penult Stress)
knots.Nuance: Proparoxytone nouns shift stress to the penultimate syllable in Gen Pl. Paroxytone nouns maintain columnar stress. Derived mostly from Ancient Greek 3rd declension [1, 2].
Forms match corresponding Masc declensions (2.1.1/2.1.6). Article determines natural gender [27].
Personal verbs inflect for person/number and must agree with the subject NP.
Impersonal verbs (πρέπει, μπορεί) followed by a να-clause express modalities (obligation, possibility, inference).
